bibl.title: Despatch from J.M. Preston to William H. Seward, August 12, 1865
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

body.div1:
Sir,
There is, and long has been, an active trade in Slaves, amounting to several hundreds a year, I can not give exact figures, Carried on between Princes and St. Shome, (Portuguese islands 150 miles west of Gaboon) and Gaboon + Coast South. Last year I coasted as far as 2^o60 South. On the way I saw a schoner of about 100 tons burden, which had been boarded by the agent of an English factory the day before, and found to be "full of slaves" I also saw a boat, capable of carrying 30 or 40 persons, but *darkup prevented our disting* wishing what is contained. On a porvised voyage our vessel sae three such slave-boats. We have children in our school taken from such boats, and given to are Mission to be free and educated. At Cape Lopez I beamers there were two slave factories (on which I saw) when
slaves
Slaves were carried to the islands in boats and larger Canoes. <pb facs="20170615_111946"
During the present voyage I heard of a slavefactory in Pernan vas river of another large me at Cape Lopez + I saw at the latter place a schooner at anchor in the of*ing.
I had with me a son of the late Ring of Cape Lopez, who was very Communicative on the subject of the Slave trade. The Burew all about the movements of the schooner which I saw at anchor. He said she seldom carried - slaves; in engage in taking corgors of goods to the factories, + small return conquers of farina ; it has a bundle of certificate of good characters receimd* Eng. Cruisers; is owned at Process; is recognized at Gaboon as a lawful trade H.R.
This is no doubt the same schooner I saw last year a little further South.
A few months ago a Porteguese schooner from St. Paul de Loaude, bound for Princes or St. Thome put into Gaboon leaking very badly. It had a great many blacks aboard, servants to the officers +crew of the schooner, for whom regular passports had been made out at St. P de L.J learned that each citizen may taken 10 such servants according
to <pb facs="20170615_111951" to Porteguese law.
The question arises, What becomes of all these slaves? Wiener the Cash and Merchandise that pay for them? Agriculture on these islands is at a very low 266. Only small grantitues of Offcie + beacon are raised for exportation and nothingelse. So Rind of manufactures is carried .
Hence then the demand for so many slaves? Are they reshipped to and then market? This would seem profitable. An American supercargo, an acquitable of mine, was total, when there a few years ago that they counted furnish him with 200 slaves in ten days time. The schooner in which I coasted South last year, was at the islands a short time before, when the Capt. saw there a brig, with hatches down and no apperance of trade day after down and no apperance of trade day after day. When her Capt. was questioned about his trade his answer were very evasive. At the same time the
Porteguese schooners above mentioned "was about at Cape Lopez, for a cargo of Pea mets" Our captain has no doubt the brig was there for a vargo of Slaves. I have heard of there being no slaves on the island, but heard nothing of any epidemic that swept them off.
The <pb facs="20170615_112003"
The French claim Cape Lopez as well as Gaboon, yet slave trading carried on at both places almost continually. There is now a trader om Gaboon, but probably not known to the Authorities. Occasionally the Authorities here make some effort to stop it, and I have, once, in the last 5 years, taken a count and slaves . They freed the slaves + released the traders.
Such is about the sums of informaiton I have. I have communicated it, unofficially of course, to the British Consul of Fermando Po.
I am Sir your obident Servant J.M.Preston
